title: Muhammad and the Biblical Tests of Prophethood
summary: Examines whether Muhammad satisfies the biblical standards for a true prophet, including doctrinal fidelity to earlier revelation and the call to point people back to Israel’s God.

sections.content: True prophets confirm earlier revelation, exalt the God of Abraham, and never preach messages that contradict the Torah and Gospel; Muhammad’s teachings must be weighed by those criteria.
If Muhammad corrects corrupted Scripture, then deviations from the Bible are justified, and biblical tests cannot be applied to him.

Deuteronomy 13 warns that even miracle-working prophets must be rejected if they lure Israel to another god; Galatians 1:8 rejects later gospels that differ from the apostolic message, so teachings that demote Jesus or rewrite salvation fail the test.

title: Is the Gospel of Barnabas Trustworthy?
summary: Analyzes the late medieval Gospel of Barnabas often cited by Muslim apologists, assessing its historical credibility and doctrinal conformity to Scripture.

sections.content: Because the Gospel of Barnabas contradicts first-century testimony and appears centuries after the apostles, it cannot overturn the canonical witness about Jesus’ deity and crucifixion.
Since early Christians allegedly tampered with Scripture, a late gospel that agrees with Islamic claims should be preferred over corrupt canonical texts.

Luke 1:1–4 and 2 Peter 1:16–21 appeal to eyewitnesses, while Jude 3 exhorts believers to guard the faith once delivered—a standard the Barnabas text fails because it rewrites salvation history without apostolic backing.

title: Did Jesus Promise Ahmad?
summary: Evaluates the Muslim assertion that Jesus foretold Ahmad (Muhammad) in John 14–16, contrasting the Paraclete’s description with the Holy Spirit’s ministry.

sections.content: Jesus promised the Holy Spirit, not another human prophet; the Paraclete would dwell within believers, remind them of Christ’s teaching, and glorify the Son.
The Greek term parakletos was allegedly altered from periklytos, meaning ‘praised one,’ so the passages refer to Muhammad.

John 14:16–17 states the Paraclete abides forever and lives in believers, and John 16:14 stresses He glorifies Jesus—actions that only the Holy Spirit fulfills and that Muhammad never claimed for himself.

title: The Sonship of Christ vs. Islamic Misconceptions
summary: Clarifies the biblical meaning of Jesus being the Son of God and responds to assertions that the phrase implies biological offspring or polytheism.

sections.content: Sonship language reveals Jesus’ unique relationship and shared nature with the Father, not physical procreation; it anchors Christian confession of the Trinity.
Calling Jesus God’s Son assigns a consort to God or splits His unity, proving Christian theology is pagan and incoherent.
John 1:18 declares the Son reveals the unseen God, and Hebrews 1:3 says He is the radiance of God’s glory—statements about shared essence, which sit comfortably within monotheistic worship.

title: Crucifixion Witnesses and the Qur’anic Denial
summary: Explores historical and biblical evidence for Jesus’ crucifixion while engaging with Qur’anic passages that claim He was not executed.

sections.content: Multiple independent witnesses—Jewish, Roman, and Christian—attest to the crucifixion, making it the best-attested event in antiquity and central to redemption.
Qur’an 4:157 states that people only thought Jesus was crucified, so apparent evidence merely reflects divine deception or substitution.
Mark 15, 1 Corinthians 15:3–4, and extra-biblical sources like Tacitus converge on the crucifixion; Isaiah 53 already foretold the Servant’s death for sin, rooting salvation in a real sacrifice.

title: Original Sin and Human Accountability
summary: Contrasts the biblical doctrine of inherited sin with Islamic claims that humans are born morally neutral and need no atonement.

sections.content: Adam’s fall introduced corruption and death to all humanity, requiring divine intervention through Christ’s righteousness.
Each person bears only their own deeds; inherited guilt contradicts divine justice and makes repentance sufficient for wiping sin.

Romans 5:12–19 links Adam’s trespass to universal death and Christ’s obedience to justification, while Psalm 51:5 confesses sinfulness from conception, demonstrating the need for redemption beyond human effort.

title: Law and Gospel in the Life of Jesus
summary: Shows how Jesus fulfilled the Mosaic Law without abolishing it, countering arguments that Christians inconsistently apply biblical commands.

sections.content: Ceremonial shadows pointed to Christ, while moral law reflects God’s character; believers uphold the law through Spirit-led obedience, not legalism.
If Jesus abolished the law, Christians cherry-pick commands, proving the Bible is inconsistent and unreliable for moral guidance.

Matthew 5:17–19 affirms Jesus fulfilled the Law, and Romans 8:3–4 explains the Spirit empowers believers to meet its righteous requirements, preserving continuity without reverting to the old covenant system.

title: Abraham’s Seed: Israel and the Church
summary: Discusses continuity and distinction between Israel and the Church in light of God’s promises, addressing Muslim critiques that Christianity abandoned Abrahamic faith.

sections.content: The Church is grafted into Israel’s promises through Christ, sharing in Abraham’s blessings without erasing ethnic Israel’s future.
Since Jews and Christians corrupted revelation, God replaced them with a new nation centered on Mecca, making Israel’s covenants void.
Romans 11 describes the olive tree analogy where Gentiles are grafted in but warned not to boast, and Galatians 3:29 teaches that those in Christ are Abraham’s seed—unity without supersessionism.

title: Qur’anic View of the Trinity
summary: Explains the Qur’an’s caricature of the Trinity and clarifies orthodox doctrine to remove stumbling blocks for Muslim readers.

sections.content: The biblical Trinity is one Being in three coequal Persons; misunderstanding it as a triad of gods or a family unit leads to strawman arguments.
Qur’an 5:116 pictures Christians worshiping a Father, Jesus, and Mary, so the doctrine must be shirk (association of partners with Allah).

Matthew 28:19 names Father, Son, and Spirit within one baptismal name, and 2 Corinthians 13:14 blesses believers with one God’s tri-personal grace, guarding monotheism while affirming plurality of Persons.

title: Reliability of the New Testament Text
summary: Responds to claims that the Bible was corrupted before Muhammad, highlighting manuscript evidence and patristic citations.

sections.content: Over 5,000 Greek manuscripts, early translations, and church fathers quoting Scripture allow scholars to reconstruct the original New Testament with high confidence.
Since the Qur’an accuses Jews and Christians of altering revelation, textual variants in the Bible prove wholesale corruption.

Isaiah 40:8 affirms God preserves His word, and Jesus in Matthew 24:35 says His words never pass away; the sheer manuscript witness demonstrates providential preservation rather than disqualifying the text.
